Italy, Denmark, Switzerland, West Germany. Only six different languages were
necessary because Switzerland could use another language and the Flemish parts of
Belgium could listen to the Dutch part of the broadcasts. Far more important was
the difference in standards, i.e. the English system was 405 lines to the picture,
and France had 319 lines to the picture. It was a real headache for the engineers
to arrange any kind of exchange, but working through the heads of the countries they
finally covered over 400 miles with 41 TV transmitters and 80 relay stations. In
none of these was coaxial cable used at all.
HThe basic increment of programs of last July was the world soccer meets in
Switzerland. However, each country participating was going to give a program that
would be representative of the kind of material available in that country to the
network so all countries could see the program and have a commentary on at all times.
A not inconsiderable problem as you can see, but I saw several programs and it did
get across—not once was the wrong language used in the wrong country and each was
converted to the correct number of lines. The programs were astonishingly clear,
although far from as good as a local broadcast. In Switzerland they had the yearly
festival of Narcissus; in Italy, a visit to the Vatican and an address by the Pope
in five different languages; France gave several programs from Paris and Versailles;
Great Britain had a variety show; and from Glasgow there were track and field events
and Queen Elizabeth reviewing the Royal Navy. Germany showed a summer evening on
the Rhine; Holland had a show especially for the children of displaced persons.
From Copenhagen came the celebration of St. John’s Eve and in Brussels they had a
summer night on the Grande Place.
“Not only were there engineering problems, but a week or so before the programs
were to take place, an added problem came up as there was a disagreement between the
sponsoring countries and the International Federation of Musicians. It meant a
number of programs had to be changed from music to other types.” (Shows additional
pictures of what was seen and the layout of the network.)
